title: Blogs
text:
Here is a list of topics and questions that intrigued me. My curiosity has led me to learn, understand and document the answers here for public knowledge.














Cancer Screening Tests






Cancer



What cancer related medical tests we should get done?





Sep 1, 2024


Sanaz Agarwal






No matching items

title: Cancer Screening Tests
text:
Cancer is a very strange response in our body. It emerges at the cellular level as a malignant tumor, escalates to organ level to cause functional failure and ultimately leads to deterioration of bodily systems of its host. Humans are not the only victims and not the recent ones either, with the earliest cancer discovered in dinosaurs, who walked millions of years ago. Today, it is plaguing us at a global level. According to a report by the American Cancer Society

In 2022, approximately 20 million cancer cases were newly diagnosed and 9.7 million people died from the disease worldwide.

At Fred Hutch Cancer Institute, I get exposed to the science and research around cancer subtypes which are most difficult to treat. It is challenging to predict which cell will turn carcinogenic. An ever growing, concerned and health-conscious population (myself included) have questions about how we can prevent it; and in the worst case, prepare for it.
While some known prevention methods include avoiding carcinogens and applying sunscreen, they offer no assurance when genetic factors come into play. This will be explored in another blog in the future. As modern individuals (facing modern forms of diseases and epidemics) we should do our best to be prepared for what may happen in the future. This led me to wonder: What tests can I get done to ensure that I am free of cancer? I stumbled upon the answer I was looking for and I wanted to share it with everyone - get periodic screening tests done to be aware of what might be lurking inside our body.
Screening tests refer to tests done on healthy individuals before they show any signs/ symptoms. It acts as a safety measure before the onset of any disease. In the case of cancer, such tests help detect precancerous cellular changes. By the time symptoms appear, cancer may have begun to spread.
Following are the common forms of cancer screening tests. They have been discussed later in the blog.

Physical examination (assessment of the exterior body, habits and family medical history)
Laboratory tests (obtain bodily samples from patients for laboratory analysis)
Imaging tests (to image interior regions of the body)
Genetic tests (checks for hereditary causes of cancer)

If a screening test result is abnormal, diagnostic tests need to be done for further investigation into the nature of the abnormality. These secondary level tests are more specific to the organ where symptoms are shown and patient’s medical history. You should always consult your physician about diagnostic tests.
As it is imperative for us to be aware of our bodies using these screening tests and what tests are available, I would like to list down a broad and general set of tests approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF).

Lung Cancer Tests
The leading cause of cancer death in the US
The following screening tests are available:

Low-dose helical computed tomography (LDCT/ Spiral CT scan/ Helical CT scan)
Standard chest X-ray
Sputum cytology

USPSTF recommends yearly screening tests for people who satisfy all 3 criteria:

have 20+ pack-year [no. of packs of cigarettes smoked a day x number of years]
currently smoke/ quit smoking in the last 15 yrs
between the age of 50-80 yrs.



Colorectal Cancer Screening
2nd leading cause of death from cancer in the US
A stool test is a non-invasive form of test that checks for tiny amounts of blood in feces. Three types of stool tests are approved by the FDA.

Guaiac Fecal Occult Blood Test (gFOBT): It uses a chemical called guaiac to detect the presence of heme in stool samples [performed every 1 or 2 years in ages 45-80 yrs]
Fecal Immunochemical Test (FIT) - uses antibodies to detect hemoglobin protein
FIT-DNA - detects hemoglobin, in addition to certain DNA biomarkers

Stool tests can be performed every 1 to 2 years in the age group of 45-80 years. Each test has its drawbacks and advantages, consult your healthcare provider to know which one is best for you.
Invasive tests include tests that can find abnormal colon growths (polyphs).

Sigmoidoscopy [done every 5 to 10 years]
Colonoscopy [done every 10 years]

USPSTF recommends colorectal screening for people at average risk of colorectal cancer from age 45 to 75. Beyond 75, as per the individual’s medical history basis.
In July 2024, FDA approved Guardant Health’s Shield Blood Test. A research paper shows evidence that this test is 83% effective in finding colorectal cancers.


Breast Cancer Tests
2nd leading cause of death from cancer for women in US
A basic Breast Self Exam (BSE), can be done at home to check for lumps or anything out of normal. Another test, namely Clinical Breast Exam (CBE) can be conducted by your healthcare provider. Being professionals, they are more suited to identifying lumps. For a more scientific approach, screening mammograms are conducted to detect tumors that cannot be detected in CBE.
USPSTF recommends biennial screening mammography for women between 40 to 74 years of age.
If any symptom of cancer has been found, a more intensive diagnostic mammogram is conducted. It includes 3D Mammography (or Digital Breast Tomosynthesis), breast ultrasounds and breast MRIs.


Cervical Cancer Tests
4th most common cancer in women globally
The following tests are available:

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) test
Pap (Papanicolaou) test / Pap smear
HPV/ Pap co-test

The updated and preferred test recommended by the American Cancer Society (ACS) is a primary HPV test for women between ages 25-65 every 5 years.

If primary HPV testing is not available, screening may be done with either a co-test that combines an HPV test with a Papanicolaou (Pap) test every 5 years or a Pap test alone every 3 years - ACS



Not every cancer has a screening test
The main purpose of a screening test is to find signs of cancer before symptoms start appearing. It’s efficacy is also measured by the extent a test is able to reduce the risk of cancer related deaths. Prostate, pancreatic, liver, ovarian, skin, testicular, thyroid, oral and brain cancers are some of the cancer subtypes for which no current screening tests have shown to reduce deaths from those cancers. Unfortunately, they typically are not diagnosed until they are advanced, very difficult to treat, and highly lethal. While research and ongoing clinical trails should yield a solution in the future, there is no standard form of screening tests available for these cancers. Despite this, a number of tests can be conducted based on patient history and should be consulted with a physician.

Liver Cancer Test - a combination of alpha-fetoprotein blood test and liver ultrasound is the most common form of test used.
Ovarian Cancer Test - CA-125 Blood test + transvaginal ultrasound/transvaginal sonography
Prostate Test - PSA Blood Test + Digital Rectal Exam [USPSTF recommends 55-69yrs
Skin Cancer (most common form of cancer in the US) - skin exam by physician



What are Multi-cancer Detection Tests (MCD)?
MCDs are tests which check for biomarkers / tumor markers using any body fluids as samples. Tumor markers could be any dysregulated gene or protein expression or a gene mutation which is a strong indicator of presence of cancer cells. No MCD tests have been approved by the US FDA. Nonetheless, several companies offer MCD tests as Laboratory Developed Tests (LDTs) to physicians and consumers. Following CLIA regulations (1988), these tests are not required to provide evidence that they provide a clinical benefit to patients, like early cancer diagnosis.
Examples of tumor markers include CA-125 (ovarian cancer), CA-19 (pancreatic cancer), estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor (breast cancer), CEA (colon cancer), PCA3 mRNA and TMPRSS2-ERG gene fusion (in prostate cancer), and EGFR gene mutation (in non-small cell lung cancer)


Word of caution!
A number of things must be kept in mind before your start knowing which screening tests are suitable for you. It involves a lot of things including you and your family’s medical history, genetic screening in some cases, lifestyle choices, mental and physical preparedness. Some of these tests, conducted repeatedly or incorrectly can place a heavy toll on your body. Ask your physician about when to start screening, and how often to be screened.
While the tests are formulated with utmost rigor and the best interests of people in mind, they still are not 100% reliable tests. The screening tests developed so far are not a one-size-fits-all or one-test-for-all kind of tests. They are susceptible to false positives and can lead to unnecessary anxiety by the results. Overdiagnosis or undertreatment can happen in certain cases. Some of the tests mentioned above involve radiation which can deteriorate the body upon prolonged exposure. A big concern is the possibility of a false-negative result: Cancer can be lurking within the body and yet the test might show a healthy result. Cancer is an evolving disease, and while scientists and clinicians are able to understand a good part of it, they are humble in accepting that there is still a lot to discover.
For further information, please read What Screening Statistics Mean


Sources

American Breast Cancer Foundation
National Cancer Institute
American Cancer Society

title: Sanaz Agarwal
text:
Hello! I am Sanaz Agarwal, a passionate Bioinformatician/ Computational Biologist and currently working at Fred Hutch Cancer Center, Seattle, WA. I use cancer biology, molecular biology and advanced computational algorithms to interpret data from cancer patients to identify the mutations and differential gene expression profiles. In addition to this, I enjoy building workflows, apps and dashboards for seamless data analysis, monitoring and visualization.
I am fascinated by the Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) technologies that have emerged in the last two decades and opened many new frontiers of molecular analysis. My passion lies in using smarter computing tools and workflows to automate all the analysis and advance towards precision medicine.
Besides work, I enjoy drinking chai (it’s not chai tea) and working out. I am a swimmer, having represented and won several National and State level championships in India. For recreation, I also play the piano.

Education

MS, Biomedical Engineering
Johns Hopkins University


Bachelors, Biochemical Engineering and Biotechnology
Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi, India



Key Research Interests

Single Cell RNA Analysis - QC methods, Unsupervised clustering, Pseudobulk analysis, Differential gene expression
Variant Calling - Structural and Genomic variants, Annotation
NGS Nanopore Sequencing - Basecalling, Adaptive Sampling, Epigenetic marker identification
Environments and Workflows - Dockers, Conda, WDL, Nextflow, Snakemake

title: Publications
text:

Gujarati S, Roy P, Agarwal S, Madhav M, Gupta I, Syamantak M, Kochar SK, Gupta D, and Das A. Natural Antisense Transcripts and DNA Methylation in Clinical Isolates of Plasmodium falciparum Malaria. Poster
KohliS., Yandhiri D., Agarwal S., Gupta I., & Brahmachari V. Characterization of the Male-Specific Chromatin Organization and its Role in Heterochromatin Formation in the Mealybug M. hirsutus (manuscript in preparation)

title: Research
text: Welcome to my research webpage! This portfolio showcases my journey through the cutting-edge landscape of bioinformatics and computational biology. As the field of bioinformatics continues to evolve, I remain dedicated to leveraging emerging technologies and methodologies to drive meaningful discoveries in cancer research, infectious diseases, and beyond.

title: Research
text:
Single-cell RNA-seq
Performed quality control, batch correction, unsupervised clustering and identification of differentially expressed genes in samples from cancer (Acute Myeloid Leukemia) patients with various genetic mutations. Analyzed for inter-cellular heterogeneity using DEGs and gene annotation. Utilized methods like batch normalization and anchoring common cellular expressions for batch effect removal.

Key Contributions

Developed Seurat, scanpy and scvi-tools end-to-end workflows using R, Python and WDL
Used DoubletFinder, Harmony, ComBat, DESeq2, SCTransform(v2) according to best practices
Developed Single Cell Quality Control Tool for end users for interactive visualization of raw data
Generated custom Docker images for each task

title: Cutting-Edge Bioinformatics Research Portfolio
text:
February 2024 - Present

Spearheading intratumor heterogeneity analysis using cutting-edge single-cell tools:

Seurat
Scanpy
scvi-tools

Conducting comprehensive genotype analysis of oncogenes in Leukemia patients:

GATK tools
Annovar
BCFtools

Pioneering WDL workflows with Docker for streamlined file management and automated clinical analysis on AWS servers



















August 2022 – January 2024

Key AchievementsSkills Showcase



Developed a high-speed Python workflow for 16s rRNA probe identification:

Utilized 20 distinct features
Successfully identified 30+ pathogenic species
Achieved runtime of less than 10 minutes

Established a cutting-edge NGS pipeline for rapid blood-stream infection bacteria detection:

Implemented Guppy for base-calling
Enabled early diagnosis in less than 1 day
















January 2021 – August 2022

Groundbreaking ResearchTechnical InnovationsVisualization



Pioneered WGS using NGS Nanopore sequencing on:

Mealybugs
Plasmodium species

Aim: Epigenome discovery in previously unexplored organisms




Leveraged GPUs and parallel computing to optimize large data processing:

Reduced computing time for Malaria analysis to ~10 hours
Facilitated early diagnosis capabilities

Implemented advanced Nanopore sequencing techniques:

UNCALLED
ReadUntil for adaptive sampling
Increased accuracy from 56% to 78%

title: Research
text:
Variant Calling
Developed optimized workflows to integrate variant calling, file parsing and formatting from multiple tools for identification of multiple forms of structural and genomic variants in Leukemia patients. Testing sequencing methods to outperform conventional cytogenic testing for rapid diagnosis.

Key Contributions

Integrating GATK, BCFtools, VarScan2, Pindel, VEP, ichorCNA, Manta for multifaceted variant search
Developed Docker images for each task within a combined WDL workflow

title: Research
text:
Nanopore Sequencing
Performed basecalling on novel mealybugs and species from Plasmodium genus (source of Malaria). Aligned with a reference genome using minimap2 and calculated methylation probability score at per CpG site for epigenetic marker identification. Explored epigenetic distribution to study impact in facultative heterochromaticity.

Key Contributions

Used Dorado, Guppy, Megalodon for HAC basecalling using 5mC, 5hmC, 6mA Remora models
Parsed BAM/SAM files with Samtools to identify methylation frequency per CpG across genome
Utilized R packages - GenomicRanges, IRanges for mapping sites against reference GCF files
Used UNCALLED, ReadUntil for adaptive sampling, increasing accuracy from 56% to 78%

title: Research
text:
Algorithm Development
Developed the first algorithm to generate probes and primers from 16s rRNA sequences of pathogenic microbiome. Incorporated a unique feature for finding best primer/ probe per taxonomic level.

Key Contributions

Developed automated pipeline to retrieve sequences from NCBI Entrez in Bash
Used Python packages - Biopython, scikit-learn, pandas, numpy, pandarallel, multiprocessing

title: Research
text:
Conclusion
To conclude, my research experience spans from single-cell RNA sequencing to novel algorithm development, each project advancing my understanding of human health and disease. This diverse skill set in advanced sequencing technologies, variant calling, and computational approaches positions me at the forefront of integrating data science with biological insights.
I aim to contribute to discoveries that can enhance our understanding of life sciences and transform patient care - early prediction, diagnosis and precision medicine.
